titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Franklin and Bertha Schweinfurth Ohlinger Papers
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday March 26, 2019 at 22:13

did.unittitle: Franklin and Bertha Schweinfurth Ohlinger Papers
did.abstract: The collection provides documentation of American Methodist mission work in China, particularly in Fujian Province, and in Korea. The Ohlingers were educational missionaries and pioneers in the field of translation and publication for the church in China. Franklin Ohlinger was born in Ohio in 1845. He served as a missionary under the Methodist Episcopal Church Foreign Mission Board beginning in 1870, based in Fuzhou, Fujian Province. He was a founder of the Union Theological School and the Anglo-Chinese College in Fuzhou. In 1887 the Ohlingers were reassigned to Korea due to conflicts with missionary colleagues in China. Following the deaths of their two younger children in Korea, the Ohlingers returned to the U.S. and Franklin returned to China as an independent missionary in 1894. He started an orphanage in Antau and was reinstated as a Methodist missionary in 1897. Ohlinger was involved in educational and literary work until his death in 1919.

accessrestrict.head: Information about Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers. Copyright has been transferred to Yale University.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: Franklin and Bertha Schweinfurth Ohlinger Papers (RG 23), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

chronitem.event: Franklin Ohlinger born near Fremont, OH; attended Wallace College in Berea, OH
Bertha Schweinfurth born in Saginaw, MI, daughter of John Schweinfurth, a Methodist circuit rider
FO arrived in Foochow, serving as missionary under the Methodist Episcopal Church Foreign Mission Board
FO organized school in Foochow, later known as Union Theological School of Foochow
FO established Zion's Herald , Methodist newspaper published in Shanghai
FO married BSO while on furlough in the U.S.
Arrived back in Foochow; engaged in literary and educational work; edited and contributed to several Methodist periodicals
Gustavus Ohlinger born
David Birchard "Bertie" Ohlinger born
FO co-founded, with Diong A-Hok, the Anglo-Chinese College in Foochow; FO was first president and BSO taught.
Wilhelma Bertha "Willa" Ohlinger born
Furlough in U.S.
Ohlingers reassigned to Korea by the Mission Board, apparently due to FO's conflicts with missionary colleagues in China
Started the first publishing house in Korea, founded the Korean Religious Tract Society, edited the Korean Repository
Bertie and Willa Ohlinger became ill and died, were buried in Korea; Ohlingers returned to U.S.

After nearly two years of lecturing in the U.S., FO returned to Hinghua, China as an independent missionary; started the Rebecca McCabe Orphanage in Antau. FO was reinstated as a Methodist missionary in 1897.
BSO returned to China, served at Rebecca McCabe Orphanage; FO worked with Methodist Press
Contance Ohlinger born
FO and BSO transferred to Foochow Conference; FO Dean of Theological School
Returned U.S.; FO then returned to China and was stationed in Shanghai while BSO and Constance lived for a time in Geneva, Switzerland
BSO and Constance returned to Shanghai
BSO and Constance in Japan for a time, due to BSO's health
FO, BSO, and Constance returned to U.S.
FO returned to China, taught at Fukien Provincial College, Foochow
Serious illness caused FO's return to U.S.
Ohlingers lived in Toledo, OH; FO lectured, translated, sought work from the Methodist mission board
Ohlingers lived in Ann Arbor, MI
FO died in Cincinnati, OH
BSO died in Columbus, OH

scopecontent.head: Description of the Papers
scopecontent.p: This record group provides valuable documentation of American Methodist mission work in China, particularly Fujian (Fukien) Province, and in Korea. Detailed and substantive letters describe the daily life and work of missionaries and interactions with Chinese Christians. The Ohlingers were pioneers in the field of translation and publication for the church in China and Korea, and founders of the Anglo-Chinese College in Fuzhou (Foochow); these aspects of their work are well documented. Franklin Ohlinger's disputes with the Methodist missionary hierarchy and subsequent detours in his missionary career are well-documented. These disputes and their consequent financial implications, added to the childhood deaths of two Ohlinger children on the mission field and frequent separations of the nuclear family, resulted in a difficult life for the Ohlingers, yet their missionary enthusiasm remained unabated.

Series I, Family Correspondence, consists primarily of letters exchanged between Franklin and Bertha, and with their son Gustavus. Correspondence is intensive and detailed for the periods when Bertha and Franklin were separated because of health problems, financial problems, or political disturbances in China. Details of family life are prominent in the letters, but mission work and political events are also described. Many of the earlier letters and some throughout the collection are written in German script.

Series II, General Correspondence, includes letters exchanged with the Methodist mission hierarchy, with both Chinese and Western colleagues on the field, and with churches in the U.S. to arrange furlough itineration. Franklin Ohlinger's particular interests in literary work and work with lepers and the blind are well represented in this correspondence. Notable correspondents include Young J. Allen, Helen Keller, Timothy Richard, William Jennings Bryan, and various bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Series III, Writing, Sermons, Speeches, provides a sampling of the Ohlingers' writings, sermons, and speeches on missionary topics. Lists of writings in the first folder of this series point to additional articles published in various periodicals. As in the case of the correspondence, about 25% of the writings are in German.
Series IV, Collected Material, primarily contains printed material documenting mission work in China and Korea.

The Personal Items and Memorabilia of Series V include well-identified photographs of the Ohlinger family and of mission work and events in Fujian during the early years of this century. A substantial amount of biographical documentation of the Ohlingers is available, some of it compiled by their daughter Constance. Contained in this series is a listing of additional Ohlinger papers that were donated to the Rutherford B. Hayes Library in Fremont, Ohio, Franklin Ohlinger's hometown.

list.item: V. Personal Items and Memorabilia, 1868-1972, n.d.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence in this series is divided into the following sections:

Franklin Ohlinger to Bertha S. Ohlinger
Bertha S. Ohlinger to Franklin Ohlinger
Bertha and/or Franklin Ohlinger to/from their children
Other family correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into the following sections:

Published writings by Franklin Ohlinger
Sermons by Franklin Ohlinger
Translations by Franklin Ohlinger
Writings and translations by Bertha S. Ohlinger

Various translations and editorials in Hwa Mei Kiao Pao , Christian Advocate , The China Methodist Forum

"The New Journalism in China" in The World's Work ; "Hsing-hua (Fuh-kien, China) Proverbs and Sayings" in T'oung Pao Archives ; "Chinese 'Carvasso's' Boyhood Recollections" in Gospel in All Lands ; "Letter to Sunday Schools" in World Wide Missions Work
Columns and letters to the editor published primarily in The North China Daily News
Typescript/ holograph articles and speeches by FO
"China, the World's Museum and a Key to the Bible"
Re. the Chinese and Korean languages customs
"Dr. Warneck on the Anti-Missionary Sentiment in Germany and her Colonies"

"A Hymn That Rallied One Thousand and More Singers"
"Musings Over My Last Mail from China"

"Suggested Topics for a History of Methodism in China"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material is organized according to topics, as listed.

did.unittitle: Re. Methodist missions in Fujian Province
Re. Christian Literature Society of Korea
Tracts: "Kim Chang Sik: A Korean Circuit Rider" "A Knight of the Cross"

Pamphlets: "The Riddle of the Universe" by Ernest Haeckel; "Hegel, Haeckel, Kossuth und das Zwolfthe Gebot" by O.D. Chwolson; Chinese language material, inc. "Hinghwa Pledge to give one tenth", calendar for first year of new Chinese republic, edicts, memorials on various subjects, 1875 issue of Zion's Herald (precursor to the Fuh-kien Church Gazette ); two ms. booklets in Chinese re. principles of acupuncture

Miscellaneous clippings and items re. China, Germany, and the U.S., incl. opium reform resolution of Methodist ministers of Toledo, Ohio, and transcriptions of Imperial Edicts Concerning the Propagation of Christianity in China (1805); Scrapbook of clippings belonging to BSO
Facsimile of letter from Henry M. Stanley to F.A. Brockhaus re. Livingstone and European involvement in Africa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into the following sections:

did.unittitle: Small photograph album: Kucheng massacre, 1895; children in orphanage; Chinese hairstyles and customs
Large photograph album: Identification lists in front; includes: Family photos (1876-1910) Scenes in Foochow (1900-1910) Missionaries in Foochow Faculty of the Anglo-Chinese College
Loose photographs: Ohlinger family members, missionary colleagues
Loose photographs: Chinese individuals, incl. children in orphanage, prisoner punishment, church workers, leper school in Hinghua, opium smokers, etc.
Loose photographs: Kushan Monastery, near Foochow
Loose photographs: scenes, incl. "baby tower" for female infanticide, examination halls, etc.
Drawings and postcards, incl. anti-opium demonstration
Lantern slides, incl. faculty of Fukien Pro- vincial College
Large and mounted loose photos, incl. Centenary Missionary Conference in Shanghai, basketball team
Small photograph album: scenes and people in Korea
Loose photographs: Korea, incl. Mr. MacGowan, British archaeologist, Korean mourners, etc.
FO BSO: biographical info. compiled by daughter Constance, and by Arthur C. Boggess of Baldwin-Wallace College
FO: Obituaries, other news clippings, and tributes
BSO: Obituaries and other news clippings
FO: Biographical documents inc. ministerial licenses, missionary appointment, ordination service, itineration lecture handbills, contract with Fuhkien Provincial College
FO: Chinese calling cards, invitations to ceremonies, etc.
BSO: Biographical documents inc. school report and award cards, excerpts from diary, programs from meetings at which BSO spoke
BSO: Biographical documents inc. re. family history and her funeral service
BSO: Notes, inc.on books read, Bible study
FO BSO: Small volume Shakespeare that contains FO's penciled message to family, written in time of danger in Korea; Birthday book
Listing of Ohlinger material donated to Rutherford B. Hayes Library, Fremont, OH
2 Chinese shoes for bound feet; 1 pair small Chinese slippers
